captions.text:
Good morning, John. I'm a little bit pissed
off right now. Ok, I'm very pissed off and

one of the only things that makes me feel
better when I'm very pissed off is to reorganize

my bookshelf, so I'm gonna do that right now
while I hopefully as calmly as possible explain
to you why I'm so pissed off.

Ok, so for those of you who don't know, I
have a disease. It's a chronic illness, no

known cure for it, it's called ulcerative
colitis and it has a whole bunch of horrible

symptoms that you do not want me to explain
to you. If you really want to know you can

google it, but you probably just take my word
for it. There's a medicine for ulcerative

colitis, it's called Asacol. I've been taking
it for like five years. So the price of Asacol

kept going up and up and up and then a new
drug came on the market called Apriso and

Apriso was basically the same drug for significantly
cheaper. So I switched from Asacol to Apriso.

And then, very soon after I switched, the
company that made Asacol created a new drug

called Asacol HD.
(By the way, beautiful bookshelf all done.)

And they said to everybody, "Hey! Asacol HD
is back, it's out, it's just in time for Asacol

to go generic and it's even better than Asacol.
It's basically the exact same thing but we

can call it something different enough that
we can extend our patent. And the kicker is

Asacol used to be three hundred dollars a
month - this is only gonna be fifty dollars
a month!" And I was, of course, ecstatic.

And so for the last three months I've been
on the same medication. It's been great, I

love it, I got my auto refill all worked out
at the pharmacy so I walk in the pharmacy,

I don't even have to call beforehand, and
they get it ready for me and she's like "I

got some news for you. I'm afraid that the
price of this drug has gone up." And I'm like,

"That's not a big deal, it used to be three
hundred dollars and now it's only fifty. How

much could it have gone up?" These numbers
right here? That's how much it's gone up.

Only six hundred and twenty for me. Twelve
hundred percent increase in one month!

So this is the patient savings card that lets
me get Asacol for fifty dollars a month. So

I'm thinking maybe there's something I missed
on the card, and there is. There's an expiration

date - April 1st, 2011. Which is funny, for
a couple of reasons. One, because obviously,

ah, this card expired before April 1st, 2011.
Second, April 1st, 2011 is April Fools Day.

So they're just playing a little joke on us!
Playing a little joke on all the people who

rely on their medication to not have horrible,
painful lives.

So this thing that the pharmacist gave me
has a 1-800 number I can call. I call the

1-800 number and it says, "I'm sorry. Due
to larger than usual call volume, you may

have an extremely long wait. Would you like
to leave a message and one of our representatives

will get back to you ASAP?" And so I was like,
"Fine, I'll leave a message." The answering

machine thing said "We're sorry, the mailbox
you have called is currently full." You know

what the number should do? You should call
and it'll be an automated message saying,
"Hello! Thank you for calling. We don't care."

So yeah, I'm pissed off and I can afford it.
And I have extra medication left over. Think

of all the people who can't afford it and
don't have extra medication left over. What

are those people going to do? Why is this
ok? There's no reason the price of medication

should go up. It's the same medication that
they've been making for twenty years. They

didn't try to contact my doctor so that we
could work something out before the colossal

twelve hundred percent increase in the cost
of the medication. And the listed expiration

date on the patient savings card, April Fools
Day, was obviously just made up for fun.

I'm pissed off enough that I spent a good
part of this weekend searching for ways to

contact Warner Chilcott. Warner Chilcott being
the company that makes this medication. And

I managed, through the magic of the internet
and some investigative techniques to find

the phone number of the CEO of Warner Chilcott,
and I'm gonna call him right now. So I don't

expect Roger Boissonneault to call me back.
I did however find his email address and emailed

him. I'm gonna put the email address in the
description below and I encourage people to,

ah, think about this situation complexly,
um, be civil, and ah, let him know how you

feel, ah, about what his company's done. Hopefully
they'll change the policy. And if they don't,

John, Nerdfighteria, I think we should work
together to make Warner Chilcott a, ah, a
new curse word.

The only reason companies will stop doing
BS like this is if people stand up to it and
say, "That is not ok."

John, thank you very much. I would appreciate
it if you in your next episode help me understand

this situation complexly and stop being so
pissed off about it cause it's hard when you're

on the inside of something like this. And
obviously there are much greater injustices

in the world, and at this point I feel like
I should emphasize that this is not a me issue.

We can fix me. But that's not what we need
to do. We need to fix this for everyone. We

need to say to these companies that it's not
ok for them to Warner Chilcott us like that.

Hehehe, aha, I like the sound of that. Thanks
everyone for your well wishes, John I look
forward to your video on Wednesday.

title: The 1200% Increase in my Prescription Drug Costs

comments.text:
My medicine valcyte cost $4,000 in 2014 and it had no generic. My insurance 
gives me a 25% copay on tier 4 drugs and a $10 copay on tier 1 (generic). 

Well, last month (Jan 2015) the generic came out and so the price was going 
to be $10. Well, on the last minute they changed it to tier 4 and now my 
copay went from $890 to $812. Except how my insurance doesn't cover the 
brand name so I can't even take advantage of my discount card. 

The greed in the drug and insurance companies is too much.﻿

comments.author: ErikinMich

comments.text:
While I genuinely feel sorry for Hank and have no idea what exactly is 
going on with this particular medication, it's not reflective of the cost 
of prescription drugs in general. 

Are drugs expensive? Yes. Are we getting hosed on the cost by socialized 
medicine in other countries. Yes. Can those costs be reduced with the 
application of logical thought. Most certainly yes. 

Before someone attacks me for the comment on U.S. drug companies getting 
hosed on the price of drugs they sell overseas, I'll explain. Countries 
like Britain and Canada dictate to a drug company what they are willing to 
pay and in most cases the company is willing to take the hit and jack up 
the price on U.S. sales. 

Why not just tell the other countries to pay a higher price or kick rocks? 
The answer is something called "patent busting".

If a drug company with a U.S. patent charges more than another country is 
willing to pay for a new drug (or an older one that's still under patent) 
there are a number of other countries with no compunction about violating 
U.S. patent law who will allow their own chemical companies to read the 
U.S. patent and use it as a set of instructions on how to make the same 
drug. Since the foreign company has none of the overhead in terms of R&D, 
potential legal fees for rare or invented side effects or clinical trial 
costs, which add up to billions, they can significantly undercut the U.S. 
company in all international sales.

Therefore the U.S. company makes the choice to make significantly less 
money on sales to many foreign countries and cover their losses/placate 
shareholders on the backs of U.S. citizens. 

It's not just U.S. companies that do this, European drug companies do the 
exact same thing for the same reason.﻿

comments.author: Sulfen

comments.text:
It's a simple way to figure out how much the drug is worth. If the 
government buys the patents, it's not obvious how much they should pay. If 
the government researches the drugs themselves, it's not obvious how much 
research they should do.

It's the same reason that you pay for a computer program instead of the 
government giving them to everyone for free. Granted, the stakes are 
higher, but that doesn't change the right answer. It just makes it more 
important to pick it.
comments.author: Daniel Carrier

comments.text:
You pay both health care tax (higher than most countries) and receive 0 
healthcare for it in America. if you do not have the money to pay for life 
saving drugs, you go bankrupt and die. That's just how America works.
comments.author: The Wolfiet

comments.text: +Malcolm Name We pay health care through tax, nothing extra.
comments.author: THE BRONY WEEABOO REDDITER NECKBEARD ATHEIST

comments.text:
+Malcolm Name Yeah exactly, I'm dutch not american. But it seems to me that 
every insurance company and the like makes deals with suppliers on they're 
own. I feel thats the biggest downside to the US way of doing it and the 
reason healthcare costs way way way more over there.

In comparison, in the UK and Netherlands suppliers fight to get the big 
healthcare contracts to supply medication, replacement hips etc. When they 
can get a contract worth billions they are very happy to offer big 
discounts.

I allways found it hard to explain to certain americans that we don't have 
socialism over here. No free lunch. 

Don't know the UK situation but here the first 350euro's (~$475) of 
healthcare you pay yourself. Above that everything your insured for is 
covered to the last cent. Theres a manditory insurance for 100 euro's a 
month for basic coverage. You can get extra private insurrance. I pay an 
extra 50 for that. Dentalcare does not fall under basic coverage to give an 
example.

Except the manditory insurance for basic coverage everyone is free to get 
issurance (or not) for whatever they want. Your allways free to pay extra 
to get a specific brand of medication you want.

Individualism and lower healthcare costs can go hand in hand.
comments.author: Gert Nutterts

comments.text:
I've watched your and John's videos sporadically for quite some time, but 
have only now found out that you have UC! I, too, am a member of the IBD

tremendously, but I'm always glad to see people with IBD doing awesome 
things and inspiring people. 
Yet another reason to love Hank Green! ﻿

comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
That's where the meat of the issue really is with all social policy. That's 
what the social contract is. What portion of my freedom, property, or time, 
am I willing to give up for what society offers in return. Like, I don't 
get blare my music at 2am, and YOU don't get to either. Those are straight 
trades. Where it gets tricky is a value of service for my dollar. Or Euro, 
whatever. I'd happily pay 5$ more a hamburger for health care. That would 
only be 50$ or so a year for me, lol! But it's going to be higher. Way 
higher. No one can possibly know how high. But only fools think it will be 
free. If the govt can do that, then let's get some free food and houses 
too. Giving homeless ppl health care w out a way to stay to healthy seems a 
bit redundant to me. We will spend millions on that population alone. So, 
it will make economical sense to feed and house them. Again, I'm not saying 
that's bad. But that is a fundamental shift in American society and policy. 
That's a more socialist state. Again, not saying it's bad. But call a spade 
a spade. There is a fundamental shift our country will take as it's 
adopting govt healthcare. And the conversation should be treated as one w 
that kind of gravity. An entire shift in our world view policy wise, top to 
bottom. To over simplify to something like, "don't you think all ppl should 
have the right to free healthcare?!" Is disingenuous, creates a false 
dichotomy, and is ignoring the logical outcomes. I'm not saying you said 
that, but iv come across it here in the thread severest times.

comments.author: soum fasda

comments.text:
+John Smith Forgive me, I did not mean to insinuate that you claimed the 
ACA does anything, to my knowledge you never actually mentioned the ACA in 
any form. 

I was merely pointing out that the ACA is really pretty darn useless. It 
doesn't fix any of the ground level problems, rather it just adds another 
unnecessary layer of bureaucracy to the system and changes who pays what 
bills.

Yes, indigent people and those that abuse emergency rooms do drive up the 
costs for everyone else, however I'm not really sure what can be done about 
that in many cases. There will always be indigent people and stupid people. 
Handing those people an insurance card doesn't change the costs they run 
up, it just causes others to pay for it. 

This is a sticky problem, one that I have no idea how to fix. What I do 
know is that a standardized insurance form, tort reform, a regulatory 
framework that makes a modicum of sense and a streamlined FDA approval 
process that adds a *bulletproof* lawsuit shield to drug companies would 
rapidly cut costs by close to half. 

This is something where you're talking about people on the margins, and a 
whole heck of a lot of people would fall into the margin of being able to 
afford insurance on their own if you cut the price by 25-40% or more.

If we could drastically reduce the overhead for doctors and hospitals as 
well as drug companies many things would become affordable.

Remove the stupid regs and you can negotiate again, the way people did 50 
years ago. My grandfather once told me that at one time my father was 
dreadfully ill with pneumonia. The doctor came over to the house, provided 
the care and drugs and then sat down with my grandfather and over a cup of 
coffee they ironed out a payment that included cash as well as my 
grandfather doing some work on the doc's car and getting him a reduced 
price on oxygen for his office (my grandfather was in the compressed gas 
business).

That's where I want to go back to. Not the bullshit we have today and 
certainly not the government run garbage from Europe that killed my mothers 
cousin.
comments.author: Wilson Gulick

comments.text:
+Wilson Gulick I did not say that the ACA was the solution. I'm thinking 
something similar to what France does. This would have to also include 
fixing your problems such as penalizing for frivolous lawsuits (which would 
solve other problems as well).

People who go into an ER and cannot pay are part of the problem, When they 
don't pay, the price goes up for everyone else.
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+John Smith Also not entirely true. 

You will get the care regardless in most cases. Will it be top-notch 
experimental care without insurance or cash up front? No, but for the most 
part you'll get the care, you'll just be bankrupt afterwords. 

On the other hand, I'd rather be alive and bankrupt than dead with $250K in 
assets. 

That said, the whole point is to make this more affordable to average 
people. That means reducing the overhead cost to the people that provide 
the care. That means getting the current government system and lawyers out 
of the freaking way. 

The ACA in no way does that. It doesn't reduce overhead, it doesn't 
increase "portability" (which, in my mind was a bullshit argument from the 
jump but that's another discussion). 

What the ACA does is take an extremely inefficient system that lacks price 
incentives for... well, anything and changes who pays the bills. That's all 
it does.

On top of that, since a lot of hospitals and doctors are not going to honor 
your lower tier ACA compliant plans, if you have one you're just as screwed 
with them as without them except you have to pay the premiums for a product 
that does absolutely nothing for you. It's like paying extra for airbags 
that never go off. 

I'm not arguing that there is no place for government regulation in the 
providing of healthcare or drugs. What I'm saying is what the current 
federal and State governments are doing is completely retarded and the ACA 
only makes it worse.

The crux of my most recent prior post was that comparing the U.S. to the 
EU, Great Britain or any of the other Commonwealth counties is apples to 
oranges, not apples to apples as the person I replied to suggested it was. 

The fact that you can't negotiate a price is directly related to numerous 
factors which I elaborated on in my prior post. No one is in a position to 
negotiate prices when the person charging you those prices is in no 
position to do anything to change them. That doctor still owes what he owes 
for malpractice and still has to cover his other overhead costs as I 
explained. Those costs are inelastic. Therefore so is the price the doctor 
charges.
comments.author: Wilson Gulick

comments.text:
+Wilson Gulick We have the best health care in the world *if you can pay 
for it.* We do not necessarily have the best health care system, which you 
seem to agree with if I interpret your comment correctly. 

Another problem with our health care system is that it is practically 
impossible to negotiate a price. If you have to pay a million dollars for a 
(hypothetical) pill that will save your life, you will find a way to get 
the money. Someone in that position is in no position to negotiate. This is 
one of the reasons why costs are so high, and why the government needs to 
intervene.
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+Alex Harrison That's not entirely true.

It depends on how you weight things when determining a "good outcome". The 
studies done by the WHO and other international groups have all weighted 
the "free public" part of healthcare as the most important. 

That's how Columbia came out higher in the rankings than the U.S., which is 
total bull. No one from the U.S. is going to Columbia for life saving 
surgeries, however rich Colombians routinely come to the U.S. for something 
like a heart bypass (the same is true of Canadians who have the means). 
That wouldn't be happening if Columbia really had "better outcomes". 

Also, you can't do an apples to apples comparison between "public" health 
care in other countries and "private" care in the U.S.

First, there is no way you're going to convince anyone who really pays 
attention that they have a better chance of beating cancer in any EU or 
Commonwealth country than they do at John's Hopkins or one of the Cancer 
Centers of America hospitals. Sorry, but the U.S. has the vast majority of 
elite hospitals for surgery and oncology. I'm not saying that other 
countries don't have GOOD health care systems, but the statistics are not 
in your favor for many ailments. Just check the publication "Health 
Affairs" for an example (http://www.healthaffairs.org/press/2012_04_10.php). 
The facts are the U.S. is better at treating something like cancer. Yes, 
it's more expensive, but if it's *your life*, you're getting what you pay 
for.

Second, State governments in the U.S. are a major part of this problem. 
Each State has set up it's own insurance board which sets the rules for 
what is allowed in the State. This means that unlike automotive insurance, 
which you can easily buy online and is valid in any state, many plans 
available in one State are not available in another. Simply put, you 
generally can't buy health insurance across State lines where you can with 
automotive, home, renters, fire or any other insurance. 

This regulation has led to massive amounts of paperwork being generated for 
"compliance". If you pick up the phone directory for a large hospital in 
the U.S. you will find that a huge amount, as much as 40% in some cases, is 
dedicated to "Administrative" folks. These people are nothing but paper 
pushers who's jobs exist solely to satisfy legally required "compliance" 
paperwork in most cases. They all get a good salary and benefits that have 
to be paid, massively increasing the overhead cost of the hospital.

Then there's federal insurance regulations as well as the FDA and another 
half dozen alphabet soup federal and State agencies. All told a huge 
percentage of the money that is spent on healthcare in the U.S. goes to 
administrative costs that shouldn't exist. 

That's where most of that 6% GDP you're talking about goes to. Not HMO or 
Insurance company CEO's or profits. 

"Let's not even get into the fact that an HMO is designed to provide as 
little care as possible to you."

That is simply not true and not even possible. The HMO/insurance company 
doesn't choose what care you get, you and your doctor make that decision. 
The HMO/insurance company decides what they're willing to pay and what 
they're willing to pay for. You already got the care. 

Then there's another problem unique the the U.S. our batshit crazy tort law 
system. This is where you can sue for anything and even if your lawsuit 
fails because it's obviously frivolous, you owe nothing to the people you 
sued. They're left with massive court costs to defend themselves against 
your slander. 

This creates a system where doctors, especially anesthesiologists and 
OBGYN's carry *massive* "malpractice insurance" policies to cover them 
against lawsuits from stupid people being egged on by money hungry lawyers 
urging the filing of lawsuits for no reason. There are literally 
anesthesiologists who are making $700,000 a year and paying $500,000 of 
that in malpractice insurance premiums.  

This means that you can take the number of patients this guy sees in a 
year, and divide $500,000 by that number to arrive at just PART of the 
doc's overhead costs of seeing you. He increases what he charges you by 
that amount. 

So if I see a doctor, any doctor, he's carrying this type of insurance (by 
law usually) and he's charging me for the premium he has to pay. My 
insurance company is paying his. Peter is being robbed to pay Paul. 

Another instance of Paul getting money right out of Peter's pocket is 
pharmaceuticals. Many countries these days have relatively advanced 
chemical industries, which means they have a pharmaceutical company over a 
barrel. 

A U.S. company does business with NHS in Britain or Canada and the NHS 
lowballs the company on the price they're willing to pay for medications. 
The company has no choice because if they try to charge the real value of 
the drugs the government of the other country will simply allow their 
chemical companies to make the same drug very much cheaper and then buy it 
from them. This is called "patent busting". 

A company creates a compound and gets it through FDA trials as well as the 
comparable EU or other trials at a cost of $1 Billion +. So they have 
massive overhead. They file a patent which must describe the compound and 
how to make it. This information is publicly available. If the company 
tries to charge fair market value to say the NHS in Britain, another 
company in India, which has no overhead, looks up how to make the drug, 
makes it and sells it to the NHS (this has actually happened in the past). 
The company that spent tons of money on making the drug now gets nothing 
from the NHS, who are buying the cut price drugs from a "patent buster" in 
another country. 

So the drug company figures they'll make $0.65 cents on the dollar from the 
NHS, then make up the difference by jacking up the price in the U.S., which 
is exactly what they do.
comments.author: Wilson Gulick

comments.text:

comments.author: darius savory

comments.text:
Every single country that has a publically-funded healthcare system has 
hugely better outcomes than the (almost entirely) private system in the 
USA. I am from Australia, and have worked as a junior doctor in numerous 
public hospitals and I can tell you- for the most part, they work really 
well. In Australia, if a patient isn't either admitted to the ward or 
discharged safely home four hours after arriving, the hospital has 
"failed". It varies a bit, but most hospitals in New South Wales 
(Australia's largest state) only "fail" about 15-20% of the time. Public 
health is cheaper than private- this is why Americans pay almost twice as 
large a portion of their GDP for healthcare. I can't believe anyone is 
surprised by this. For any Americans reading who think private healthcare 
is cheaper, you are paying the profit margins, dividends and outrageous 
executive bonuses at large HMOs. This is where your extra six percent GDP 
goes- that's money out of your pocket, and almost twice as much than just 
paying a little more tax. Let's not even get into the fact that an HMO is 
designed to provide as little care as possible to you. At least with a 
public system, the benefit is mutual. Taking proper care of the patient 
makes that patient cheaper for the system in the long run. Entirely private 
systems are indefensible (though there definitely is no inherent problem 
with having a nicely balanced combined system, like Australia has). 
Compared to just about every industrialised nation, life expectancy is 
lower in the US, infant mortality is higher in the US and outcomes in 
chronic disease and cancer are worse in the US. You are being beaten on ALL 
those things by Cuba, a nation with less than a tenth as much money. I've 
seen it- I worked in their public system for several months. Food for 
thought.
comments.author: Alex Harrison

comments.text:

nice.  

1. "Junkies" shouldn't just be left to die, everybody's equal and they're

and help. They've got nothing.
2. I'm pretty sure they wouldn't ignore you. They've got to make

accidents) for about an hour with both my knees sliced open,  and the 
doctors did provide me with a cloth to stop the bleeding until they had 
time to sort it out. And I didn't die. It took some time, but that's life.
3. Yeah, I'm sure that you "actually work for a living", but guess what: 
Every job is equally as important. Right? The world needs farmers to 
produce food, teachers to educate people and rocket scientists to bring the 
world forward, but there wouldn't be a scientist without the teacher, and 
the teacher wouldn't be there without food. Okay? I doubt that you work 
harder than anyone else.

comments.text:
Anyone ever wonder why there never is any cures? Only treatments? It's 
because there is no money in cures. There is a lot of money in treatments. 
Whenever I see one of the charities collecting money to try to find a cure 
I always donated generously. But the other day I was watching the idiot box 
and I heard a charity spokesman say "please give to help us find a cure" 
That's when the light came on and I said "a cure" there has never been a 
cure that I know of, I am sure there must be a drug that has came out 
sometime to cure something but I just have never heard of it. But the major 
diseases have never found one with billions donated to help. If they do

comments.author: John M

comments.text:
We do not have the technology to create cures. We do have the technology to 
prevent diseases (vaccines) and to fight diseases (antibiotics/antivirals). 
However, to make up for the lack of technology we do have several ways to 
treat diseases so that you can live a normal life with the disease. Maybe 
one day we will find ways to cure diseases without having to rely almost 
100% on our immune system.
comments.author: Sulfen

comments.text:
I'm going to list off vaccinations because those are the best form of 
"cure" that you can imagine: a preventative measure to ensure you never 
have to suffer from a disease, therefore avoiding any need to cure it.
Diphteria, tetanus, whooping cough (pertussis), polio, Hib (Haemophilus 
influenzae type b), pneumococcal (against Streptococcus pneumoniae which 
can cause pneumonia, septicaemia and meningitis), rotavirus (causes 
gastroenteritis), meningitis C, measles, mumps, rubella, human papilloma 
virus (causes cervical cancer), shingles. Those are available to everyone 
who is on the NHS (National Health Service, our public healthcare in the 
UK). Source: 
http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/vaccinations/Pages/vaccination-schedule-age-checklist.aspx

Additionally, people in risk groups can also receive heptitis B, 
tuberculosis and chickenpox vaccinations, and those travelling abroad can 
receive (also for free) heptitis A, typhoid and cholera vaccines, and a few 
others are only done privately.

Most of the vaccines mentioned provide, after taking all the doses, near 
enough 100% immunity and many of them are permanent though some may require 
boosters or, in the case of influenza, the rate of mutation is too fast and 
new strains develop yearly. Many drugs and antibiotics manage to treat the 
cause effectively, and not just keep the symptoms at bay; I can't begin to 
mention all the names. The problem is, every time you wipe out a harmful 
bacterial colony, you exert a selective pressure that favors resistance 
genes, so mutant bacteria that develop antibiotic resistance may survive 
and then your cure no longer works. In addition to all this, many diseases 
are also caused your body doing something wrong, and this is at the level 
of the infrastructure, cell to cell signalling or a cell's regulation, 
which means that your options to correct it are limited: you either replace 
the tissue/organ entirely with expensive and potentially dangerous surgery, 
you give someone a drug that needs to be taken regularly to correct cell 
function, or you use transgenic technology (which we have not yet developed 
to this level) to correct the issue at its core.

Apologies for the long answer, I've tried to simplify the explanation and 
I'm sure I've left out so much information.
comments.author: E “Anonymous Nerdfighter” Hernandez

comments.text:
+John M 
          one word............polio.
comments.author: West Kagle

comments.text:
Here's a thought, not every condition is curable. Most are just because of 
how the persons body is, and is something that cannot be solved without 
extensive surgery/organ replacement, which might not even work for all of 
them.

As for cures? Firstly there's vaccines (which make them lose money compared 
to treating the symptoms) which help stop people getting ill in the first 
place, and for a lot of other diseases, we have medication that can treat 
it. 

I appreciate not everyone has a good grasp of biology, but there is no such 
thing as a 'cure' for most conditions or diseases. We can treat them (which 
is curing over time), or we can help the person with the symptoms and hope 
their body fights it off, but that's it. 

So not some conspiracy, or attempt to steal money from the public (as of 
they could keep something like that secret for so long in the first place), 
it's just biology, and the fact that you simply can't 'cure' everything.

comments.text:
I work as a pharmacy technician and I see this all the freaking time. You 
want to know how to fix the healthcare system? STOP giving pharmaceutical 
companies and hospitals the ability to charge whatever they want! The 
problem isn't insurance, the only reason hospitals charge so much is 
because they know the insurance companies will pay the majority of it... 
the patient isn't going to see those zeros so no one bats an eye. I sold a 
prescription to a woman who has cancer about a month ago... over $4,000 for 
a bottle of 90 capsules... won't say which medication, but I looked up the 
WHOLESALE price of the drug in our computer and it was over $40,000 for one 
bottle (the bottle had 1,000 capsules)! Ridiculous! I feel your pain... 
things are out of control and it is completely unethical to do that to 
countless individuals who may need that medication.﻿

comments.text:

comments.author: GabrielTheViking

comments.text:
I am taking six prescription drugs for various chronic conditions.  Three 
of them are incredibly cheap generics.  The other three were costing me 
about $600 per month.  Several years ago I started getting these three 
prescriptions filled in Canada for about $200 per month.  Every six months 
or so I would drive to Windsor, ON, visit a walk-in clinic, and get a 
Canadian prescription (about $35 for the exam).  My costs dropped from 
about $7200 per year to about $2470.  I would plan multi-purpose trips, so 
travel costs were negligible.

Additional savings could be achieved by using a mail-order Canadian 
pharmacy; however, you have to be very careful with mail-order drugs.  The 
only thing Canadian about many of the "Canadian pharmacy" websites is the 
URL.  Many of them are run by the Russian Mafia, so you may get nothing, or 
you may get counterfeit drugs.

Some Canadian walk-in clinics do not accept US patients, so it pays to call 
ahead.  My shortest wait at a clinic was about 10 minutes; the longest 
about 2 hours.﻿

comments.author: Christian Cervantes

comments.text:
A good example how and why the do this is sugar. Why is sugar in the US 
twice as much as the rest of the world? Because we put quotas on sugar 
imports to shrink the supply. So sugar farmers in the US can sell for 
higher than they normally could. In turn to keep this policy alive the 
farmers will fund political candidates and lobby groups.
comments.author: Seth Hollibaugh

comments.text:
The government is not going to allow that. That will make drugs much 
cheaper and therefore significant profit can't be made by the big phamas.
comments.author: Seth Hollibaugh

comments.text:
Yes, the regulation of the FDA in the product plays some part but it is 
also the way our healthcare system operates. That's the main issue here. I 
drive all the way to Mexico for my meds even though it is a dangerous trip. 
That's why I created a petition to urge the government to allow people to 
import their medication. Here it is: http://wh.gov/ldtbW I am asking for 
people who care about this issue to sign it.
comments.author: Christian Cervantes
